16 of 16 Last Video Next Video Homeland Security's plan to deport undocumented immigrants: 5 things to know Arizona family faces mom's deportation Children reunited with deported mother Deported Arizona mom reunites with children in Mexico Children and attorney of Guadalupe Garcia de Rayos react to her deportation Protest at ICE office in Phoenix Deportation protest Protesters at ICE ICE protest Protest for the release of Guadalupe Garcia de Rayos Protesters block ICE vans in protest over mom Protesters block ICE vans in protest over mom Response to Trump executive actions Trump executive actions anger local activists Here's what Trump's executive orders on immigration, border wall do How executive orders work Immigrant advocates say that while Trump's comments are encouraging, the new rules offer no guarantee the president will keep the DACA program. Protesters carry a "Dream Act Now" banner through Phoenix in 2012. President Donald Trump's executive orders spare "dreamers" from deportation. (Photo: Nick Oza/ The Republic) 
55 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE New deportation rules issued by President Donald's Trump's administration on Tuesday cast a wide net but exclude one notable group: 750,000 young undocumented immigrants known as "dreamers."
Gillian Christensen, a spokeswoman for the Department of Homeland Security, confirmed that deportation protections granted under a program created by former President Barack Obama remain in effect.
The Trump administration will honor the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals protections, unless a DACA recipient is charged with a crime that nullifies the requirements of the program, she said.
Trump actions on immigration How many Mexicans cross illegally? Deportation plan brings relief, worry Will police help with deportations? Little appetite at AZ police agencies Mass deportations: Cities unprepared Trump actions: 'People are scared' Arizona mom has been deported Why mom didn't apply for citizenship Migrants call protocols 'an attack' Trump spares 'dreamers' Trump voters cheer new guidelines Quiz: Immigration in U.S. FULL COVERAGE While carrying out a campaign promise to greatly expand deportations, Trump has expressed sympathy for so-called dreamers, undocumented immigrants brought to the U.S. as children.
"We’re going to show great heart," Trump said at a news conference last week . "DACA is a very, very difficult subject for me, I will tell you. To me, it’s one of the most difficult subjects I have, because you have these incredible kids, in many cases — not in all cases. In some of the cases they’re having DACA and they’re gang members and they’re drug dealers, too. But you have some absolutely incredible kids — I would say mostly — they were brought here in such a way — it's a very, very tough subject."
No guarantees Immigrant advocates, however, say that while Trump's comments are encouraging, the new rules issued Tuesday offer no guarantee Trump will keep the DACA program. They also fear the new rules will make it easier for immigration authorities to revoke deportation protections for even minor traffic infraction, such as speeding.
“I think what we were expecting is an explicit decision about DACA, and we certainly haven’t gotten that yet.”
Kamal Essaheb, director of policy and advocacy for National Immigration Law Center. "I think what we were expecting is an explicit decision about DACA, and we certainly haven’t gotten that yet, said Kamal Essaheb, director of policy and advocacy for National Immigration Law Center.
The sweeping DHS memos issued Tuesday instruct Immigration and Customs Enforcement and U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents to immediately begin implementing deportation rules that put virtually all of the nation's 11 million undocumented individuals at risk of deportation. The new rules, which rescind narrower deportation priorities put in place by the Obama administration, broaden deportation priorities to include not just immigrants convicted of crimes, but those charged with crimes and those who have "committed acts which constitute a chargeable criminal offense."
MORE: Migrants on Trump memos: 'What came out today is scary' 
The memos, however, specifically exempt dreamers covered by Obama's 2012 DACA program, as well two other programs Obama created in 2014 to shield from deportation additional groups of undocumented immigrants.
One program expanded the number of dreamers who qualified for the original DACA program. The other, called Deferred Action for Parents of Americans, offered the same deportation protections and work permits to certain undocumented immigrants with children who are either U.S. citizens or legal permanent residents. The two programs, however, were never implemented after they were blocked by the courts.

Nick Oza/The Republic Fullscreen Families who are directly impacted by President Donald Trump's announcement on immigration attend a Puente Arizona-Grassroots Organizing for Human Rights gathering on Jan. 25, 2017. Lopez said, "I'm scared because of my daughter ... who qualifies for deferred action."  Nick Oza/The Republic Fullscreen Puente Arizona-Grassroots Organizing for Human Rights representatives talk to families who are directly impacted by President Donald Trump's announcement on immigration on Jan. 25, 2017.  Nick Oza/The Republic Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 19 2 of 19 3 of 19 4 of 19 5 of 19 6 of 19 7 of 19 8 of 19 9 of 19 10 of 19 11 of 19 12 of 19 13 of 19 14 of 19 15 of 19 16 of 19 17 of 19 18 of 19 19 of 19 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide DACA recipients' concerns Thomas Kim, an Arizona State University law student and DACA recipient originally from South Korea, worries the new rules will make it easy for immigration enforcement authorities to rescind DACA for even minor infractions.
"DACA can be rescinded on an individual basis by the government for any reason, really," Kim said. "This memo essentially makes everybody a priority for removal, which puts DACA recipients in danger of arrest. Even if we just get a traffic ticket, they could make case that we're a public-safety risk."
The new rules are especially concerning because they call for ICE to renew partnerships with local police agencies to train officers on the street to double as immigration-enforcement agents, increasing the likelihood that DACA recipients will be placed in the cross-hairs of federal immigration authorities, said Reyna Montoya, a DACA recipient originally from Mexico who is executive director of Aliento, a Phoenix-based advocacy group.
RELATED: Trump supporters cheer new guidelines on deportation 
In the past, DACA recipients with fewer than three misdemeanor convictions generally were allowed to remain in the country, she said.
“It’s very important for people with DACA to understand it could be taken away for a simple mistake.”
Karina Ruiz, executive director of the Arizona Dream Act Coalition She cited two recent examples that suggest ICE already is getting tougher with DACA recipients: the arrest of 23-year-old DACA recipient Daniel Ramirez Medina in Seattle, who ICE officials say is a " self-admitted gang member," according to the Los Angeles Times , and 19-year-old DACA recipient Josue Romero, who was taken into ICE custody after being arrested on a misdemeanor marijuana possession charge, according to the San Antonio Express-News .
"We see the cases in Washington state ... and in Texas, where (federal immigration authorities) didn’t really respect DACA," Montoya said.
Karina Ruiz, a DACA recipient from Mexico and executive director of the Arizona Dream Act Coalition, is cautioning DACA recipients to do everything they can to avoid contact with the police.
"It’s more fragile than ever under this administration," she said. "It’s very important for people with DACA to understand it could be taken away for a simple mistake."
Reporters Maria Polletta of The Arizona Republic and Alan Gomez of USA Today contributed to this article.
